syllabus_info.syllabus_name: Cambridge International AS & A Level Chemistry 9701

learning_objectives.description: recall the reactions (reagents and conditions) by which phenol can be produced: (a) reaction of phenylamine with HNO₂ or NaNO₂ and dilute acid below 10°C to produce the diazonium salt; further warming of the diazonium salt with H₂O to give phenol

recall the chemistry of phenol, as exemplified by the following reactions: (a) with bases, for example NaOH(aq) to produce sodium phenoxide (b) with Na(s) to produce sodium phenoxide and H₂(g) (c) in NaOH(aq) with diazonium salts, to give azo compounds (d) nitration of the aromatic ring with dilute HNO₃(aq) at room temperature to give a mixture of 2-nitrophenol and 4-nitrophenol (e) bromination of the aromatic ring with Br₂(aq) to form 2,4,6-tribromophenol
describe and explain the relative acidities of water, phenol and ethanol
explain why the reagents and conditions for the nitration and bromination of phenol are different from those for benzene
recall that the hydroxyl group of a phenol directs to the 2-, 4- and 6-positions
apply knowledge of the reactions of phenol to those of other phenolic compounds, e.g. naphthol
